repnme.cdata!:
Slovak Republic - Enterprise and Financial
            Sector Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Enterprise and
            Financial Sector Adjustment Loan (EFSAL) Project for the
            Slovak Republic was highly satisfactory with highly likely
            sustainability, substantial institutional development impact
            and satisfactory performances by both the Bank and the
            Borrower.  The Slovak authorities remained strongly
            committed to the banking and enterprise sector reforms
            throughout the EFSAL implementation period.  Lessons learned
            included: A) The loan was appropriately designed in
            conjunction with the IMF SMP and as a multi-tranche
            operation with a sufficiently long implementation period, in
            line with the complexity and broad span of activities
            envisaged under the operation. B) A key success factor was
            Commitment to Reform by both the Slovak authorities and the
            Bank. C) The project coherence with the Bank's Slovakia
            AAA Program helped to define the pace and direction of the
            reforms. In addition, these Bank activities deepened the
            understanding and buy-in of the reforms needed, and helped
            build institutional capacity to implement laws and
            regulations. D) The project demonstrated that a challenging
            and complex multi-sector adjustment loan can be successfully
            implemented in a very short time period under the right
            circumstances. Drawing on the lessons learned from the
            EFSAL, the Bank could implement similar adjustment
            operations/programs in other countries facing similar circumstances.

docna.cdata!:
Slovak Republic - Enterprise and Financial
            Sector Adjustment Loan Project

            Financial Sector Adjustment Loan Project

5606208.trustfund:
TF025585-PHRD-SECOND FINANCIAL &
            ENTERPRISE SECTOR ADJ.LOAN/CREDIT 2,TF025813-PHRD-ENTERPRISE & FINANCIAL
            SECTOR ADJUSTMENT

repnme.cdata!:
Slovak Republic - Enterprise and Financial
            Sector Adjustment Loan Project : release of the Third
            Tranche - Full Compliance

abstracts.cdata!:
The Slovak authorities have completed
            the implementation of the Program, as evidenced by the
            successful restructuring and privatization of the three
            large former state-owned banks, resolution through sale,
            closure or corrective action of all smaller problem banks,
            strengthening of bank supervision, and enactment of new
            legislation in the areas of  banking, insurance, and
            securities markets, commercial law and secured lending.
            Additionally, satisfactory progress has been made towards
            resolving public sector arrears, and bad loans taken off the
            books of the state banks, and preparation of new laws on
            bankruptcy, and regulation of  bankruptcy trustees. These
            reforms have contributed to higher economic growth, a
            reduction in unemployment, and substantial foreign direct
            investment inflows.  On this basis, and also taking into
            account that all third tranche release conditions specified
            in the Loan Agreement have been met, it is justified to
            release the third tranche of the Loan. In view of the
            overall performance and progress with the implementation of
            the Program supported by the Loan, and in compliance with
            the specific conditions of release as described in Schedule
            3, Section II of the Loan Agreement, the Bank has informed
            the Borrower of the availability of the third tranche of EUR
            70 million.

3291180.trustfund:
TF025585-PHRD-SECOND FINANCIAL &
            ENTERPRISE SECTOR ADJ.LOAN/CREDIT 2,TF025813-PHRD-ENTERPRISE & FINANCIAL
            SECTOR ADJUSTMENT

repnme.cdata!:
Slovak Republic - Enterprise and Financial
            Sector Adjustment Loan - release of the Second Tranche -
            Full Compliance

abstracts.cdata!:
The Enterprise and Financial Sector
            Adjustment Loan, in accordance with the Government's
            enterprise and financial sector reform program, comprised
            four components: a) restructuring and privatization of the
            banking system, but also including resolution of all
            troubled medium-sized banks; b) substantial strengthening of
            banking regulation and supervision; c) implementation of a
            strategy to resolve the large stock of problem loans taken
            off the books of the state banks; and, d) improving the
            legal framework, centered on the bankruptcy and collateral
            regime, and laws dealing with corporate governance. While
            rapid progress was made with implementation of the first two
            components, selected reforms supporting implementation of
            the last two components however, were noticeably slower to
            materialize. Therefore, release of the second tranche
            slipped from its original target date of early 2002, to well
            into 2003. Nonetheless, the pace of reform implementation
            accelerated noticeably during late 2002 and early 2003, also
            due to Slovakia's pending EU accession in May 2004,
            and, developments so far in 2003, and prospects for next
            year are encouraging. However, important risks remain: on
            the fiscal side, legislative changes relating to the
            spending reforms still need Parliament approval, and,
            outside the state budget, better control over municipalities
            and the health sector is needed, to avoid further slippages.
            Monetary policy continues to face a difficult balance
            between reducing inflation, and containing speculative
            capital inflows. Notwithstanding, progress against the
            second tranche release, and its conditions specified in the
            Loan Agreement have been met. In view of the overall
            performance, and progress with the implementation of the
            Program supported by the Loan, and in compliance with the
            specific conditions of release as described in Schedule 3,
            Section I of the Loan Agreement, the Bank has informed the
            Borrower of the availability of the second tranche of EURO
            70 million.

repnme.cdata!:
Slovak Republic - Enterprise and Financial
            Sector Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Enterprise and Financial Sector
            Adjustment Loan Project, aims to support the
            Government's comprehensive program of bank, and
            enterprise reforms. The program contains four broad
            components: 1) restructuring, and privatization of the
            banking system, centered on the privatization of the three
            large State banks, but including too, the resolution of all
            troubled medium banks; 2) substantial strengthening of
            banking regulation, and supervision; 3) full implementation
            of a strategy to workout the large stock of classified
            claims; and, 4) substantial improvements in the legal
            framework, centered on the bankruptcy, and collateral
            regimes, and, the laws dealing with corporate governance.
            Reform actions, sought under the project, will improve the
            stability, and efficiency of the banking system; promote
            enterprise restructuring; and, attract foreign investment,
            to ultimately contribute to employment, and output growth in
            the longer-run. Nonetheless, there are risks involved to the
            project, mostly due to the political situation: the broad
            coalition could interrupt implementation of some project
            components, if faced with adverse short-run effects of the
            reforms, such as unemployment, or a very low price for the
            bad assets. However, this risk seems to be modest, given the
            advanced implementation stage of reforms.
